P​r​(|cos⁡(θxi,xj)|>log⁡nn)<1n.𝑃𝑟subscript𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝑛𝑛1𝑛Pr\left(|\cos(\theta_{x_{i},x_{j}})|>\sqrt{\frac{\log n}{n}}\right)<\frac{1}{n}.

As n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty there is high probability every pair of vectors has inner product ≈0absent0\approx 0.

Proof 1: Any pair of vectors sampled from 2 random datasets are almost always orthogonal

While Lemma 2 gives us intuition into the concentration of measure phenomenon, it is limited to random vectors uniformly sampled from the unit hypersphere. To extend the proof to vectors sampled from 2 random datasets, we can no longer assume the vectors are uniformly drawn from the unit hypersphere. Instead we assume that 𝒟1∈ℝn1×fsubscript𝒟1superscriptℝsubscript𝑛1𝑓\mathcal{D}_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}\times f} and 𝒟2∈ℝn2×fsubscript𝒟2superscriptℝsubscript𝑛2𝑓\mathcal{D}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}\times f} where n𝑛n is the number of samples and f𝑓f is the number of features. We assume that the datasets are drawn from two distinct and independent distributions, i.e., the 2 datasets share no information, and that both datasets have been standardized (a common practice in deep learning tasks). If we take xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} and xjsubscript𝑥𝑗x_{j} as vectors that come from datasets 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} such that xi∼N​(0,Σ1)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑖𝑁0subscriptΣ1x_{i}\sim N(0,\Sigma_{1}) and xj∼N​(0,Σ2)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑗𝑁0subscriptΣ2x_{j}\sim N(0,\Sigma_{2}). As 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} are drawn from distinct and independent distributions, their covariance matrices are also independent. Note that Σ1subscriptΣ1\Sigma_{1} and Σ2subscriptΣ2\Sigma_{2} are not necessarily diagonal matrices, implying that the components of the vectors in each dataset are not always independent. Using Lemma 1 and the fact the two vectors are independent of each other, E​[xi⋅xj]=E​[xi]​E​[xj]=0𝐸delimited-[]⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝐸delimited-[]subscript𝑥𝑖𝐸delimited-[]subscript𝑥𝑗0E[x_{i}\cdot x_{j}]=E[x_{i}]E[x_{j}]=0 and V​a​r​[xi⋅xj]=E​[(xi⋅xj)2]−0=E​[(∑k=1fxi​k​xj​k)2]=∑k=1fE​[xi​k2]​E​[xj​k2]𝑉𝑎𝑟delimited-[]⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝐸delimited-[]superscript⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗20𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑓𝐸delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑖𝑘𝐸delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑗𝑘Var[x_{i}\cdot x_{j}]=E[(x_{i}\cdot x_{j})^{2}]-0=E[\left(\sum_{k=1}^{f}x_{ik}x_{jk}\right)^{2}]=\sum_{k=1}^{f}E[x^{2}_{ik}]E[x^{2}_{jk}]. This final simplification holds as the two vectors are independent with no covariance. As the features are symmetrically distributed about 0 with a variance of 1 due to Z-score normalization E​[xi​k2]​E​[xj​k2]≈1𝐸delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑖𝑘𝐸delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑗𝑘1E[x^{2}_{ik}]E[x^{2}_{jk}]\approx 1. Then, using the Chebyshev inequality and the central limit theorem (applicable as f,n>>30much-greater-than𝑓𝑛30f,n>>30), we can bound the probability that the absolute value of the cosine of the angle between a pair of randomly drawn vectors from the two datasets exceeds a threshold t𝑡t

P​r​(|cos⁡(θxi,xj)|>t)<V​a​r​[xi⋅xj]​1nt2≈1n​t2.𝑃𝑟subscript𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝑡𝑉𝑎𝑟delimited-[]⋅subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗1𝑛superscript𝑡21𝑛superscript𝑡2Pr\left(|\cos(\theta_{x_{i},x_{j}})|>t\right)<\frac{Var[x_{i}\cdot x_{j}]\frac{1}{n}}{t^{2}}\approx\frac{1}{nt^{2}}.

Note this holds as the datasets are independent with no shared information. However, if the datasets are not independent due to underlying common features, this bound no longer holds and we expect randomly drawn vectors to be non-orthogonal. Note similarly to Lemma 2, this orthogonality holds as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty. In particular, it must scale as a function of dataset size.

C.2 Weight Divergence in FL

Outline: Now we link model updates to the relative orientation of data vectors. We then show that when vectors from independent datasets are oriented differently, weight divergence occurs. This motivates our choice of cosine similarity to measure feature cost.

Preliminaries

  1. 1.

    Update steps in gradient descent are given by the equation wi+1:=wi−η​∇wLassignsuperscript𝑤𝑖1superscript𝑤𝑖𝜂subscript∇𝑤𝐿w^{i+1}:=w^{i}-\eta\nabla_{w}L where ∇wLsubscript∇𝑤𝐿\nabla_{w}L denotes the gradients with respect to the weights, and η𝜂\eta is the learning rate.

  2. 2.

    Using the chain rule, for a 1 layer network, we can decompose ∇wLsubscript∇𝑤𝐿\nabla_{w}L further to ∇wL=∂L∂ϕ⋅ϕ′​(w⋅x)⋅xsubscript∇𝑤𝐿⋅⋅𝐿italic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤𝑥𝑥\nabla_{w}L=\frac{\partial L}{\partial\phi}\cdot\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x)\cdot x where ϕ′superscriptitalic-ϕ′\phi^{\prime} is the derivative of the activation function. This can be used to decompose multi-layer networks as well.

  3. 3.

    Each input data point x𝑥x can be broken into two components, one that is parallel to the weight vector w𝑤w, denoted x∥subscript𝑥parallel-tox_{\parallel}, and one that is perpendicular, denoted x⟂subscript𝑥perpendicular-tox_{\perp}. Formally, we express this as x=x∥+x⟂𝑥subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥perpendicular-tox=x_{\parallel}+x_{\perp}, where x∥=(x⋅w)​w‖w‖2subscript𝑥parallel-to⋅𝑥𝑤𝑤superscriptnorm𝑤2x_{\parallel}=\frac{(x\cdot w)w}{||w||^{2}} and x⟂=x−x∥subscript𝑥perpendicular-to𝑥subscript𝑥parallel-tox_{\perp}=x-x_{\parallel}.

  4. 4.

    When vectors a,b,c𝑎𝑏𝑐a,b,c are normalized (i.e., ||.||=1||.||=1), the cosine similarity, or dot product, follows the following inequality |cos⁡(a,b)−cos⁡(a,c)|≤2​(1−cos⁡(b,c))𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑐21𝑏𝑐|\cos(a,b)-\cos(a,c)|\leq\sqrt{2(1-\cos(b,c))}. This is arrived at by using the Cauchy Schwarz inequality |a⋅(b−c)|=|a⋅b−a⋅c|≤‖a‖​‖b−c‖=‖b−c‖⋅𝑎𝑏𝑐⋅𝑎𝑏⋅𝑎𝑐norm𝑎norm𝑏𝑐norm𝑏𝑐|a\cdot(b-c)|=|a\cdot b-a\cdot c|\leq||a||||b-c||=||b-c|| and ‖b−c‖2=‖b‖2+‖c‖2−2​b⋅c=2​(1−cos⁡(b,c))superscriptnorm𝑏𝑐2superscriptnorm𝑏2superscriptnorm𝑐2⋅2𝑏𝑐21𝑏𝑐||b-c||^{2}=||b||^{2}+||c||^{2}-2b\cdot c=2(1-\cos(b,c)).

Lemma 3: Weight update is proportional to the parallel component of the input vector

Let g=∇wL𝑔subscript∇𝑤𝐿g=\nabla_{w}L. In a one-layer network, we can express g𝑔g in terms of the input vector, g=∇ϕL⋅ϕ′​(w⋅x)⋅x𝑔⋅subscript∇italic-ϕ⋅𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤𝑥𝑥g=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x)\cdot x. Decomposing x𝑥x leads to g=∇ϕL⋅(ϕ′​(w⋅(x∥+x⟂))​(x∥+x⟂))=∇ϕL⋅(ϕ′​(w⋅x∥)​x∥+ϕ′​(w⋅x⟂)​x⟂)𝑔⋅subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥perpendicular-tosubscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥perpendicular-to⋅subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥parallel-tosuperscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥perpendicular-tosubscript𝑥perpendicular-tog=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\left(\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot(x_{\parallel}+x_{\perp}))(x_{\parallel}+x_{\perp})\right)=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\left(\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\parallel})x_{\parallel}+\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\perp})x_{\perp}\right) However, w⋅x⟂=0⋅𝑤subscript𝑥perpendicular-to0w\cdot x_{\perp}=0 so we get g=∇ϕL⋅ϕ′​(w⋅x∥)​x∥𝑔subscript∇italic-ϕ⋅𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥parallel-tog=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\parallel})x_{\parallel}. Assuming we are in the linear region of the ReLU activation function and so ϕ′​(w⋅x∥)=1superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-to1\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\parallel})=1, this leaves us with

Δ​w∝g=∇ϕL⋅x∥.proportional-toΔ𝑤𝑔subscript∇italic-ϕ⋅𝐿subscript𝑥parallel-to\Delta w\propto g=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot x_{\parallel}.

Hence, the update to w𝑤w is proportional to the component of the input vector x𝑥x that is parallel to w𝑤w, scaled by the gradient of the loss with respect to the activation function output. Note in a multi-layered network we replace g=∇ϕL⋅ϕ′​(w⋅x∥)​x∥𝑔subscript∇italic-ϕ⋅𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥parallel-tog=\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\parallel})x_{\parallel} with g∝f​(k′)​∇ϕL⋅ϕ′​(w⋅x∥)​x∥proportional-to𝑔𝑓superscript𝑘′subscript∇italic-ϕ⋅𝐿superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅𝑤subscript𝑥parallel-tosubscript𝑥parallel-tog\propto f(k^{\prime})\nabla_{\phi}L\cdot\phi^{\prime}(w\cdot x_{\parallel})x_{\parallel} where f​(k′)𝑓superscript𝑘′f(k^{\prime}) is a function that encapsulates the chain of derivative products with respect to deeper layers. Importantly, even in the multi-layer case, there is still a dependence on x∥subscript𝑥parallel-tox_{\parallel}

Remark 2:

  • •

    In deeper networks, this relationship may only hold in the early layers. However, its been shown that early layers function to extract fundamental features from the dataset that are used by deeper layer (Zeiler and Fergus, 2014; Yosinski et al., 2015). Thus, the relationship will still have implications for a deeper network.

  • •

    Further, assuming neural networks act as a mapping function from input space X𝑋X to output space Y𝑌Y and that this function is Lipschitz continuous, we can invoke the smoothness assumption. Formally, ∃K:∀x1,x2∈X⇒dY​(f​(x1),f​(x2))≤K​dX​(x1,x2):𝐾for-allsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝑋⇒subscript𝑑𝑌𝑓subscript𝑥1𝑓subscript𝑥2𝐾subscript𝑑𝑋subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2\exists K:\forall x_{1},x_{2}\in X\Rightarrow d_{Y}(f(x_{1}),f(x_{2}))\leq Kd_{X}(x_{1},x_{2}). This essentially means that data points which are proximate in the feature space will continue to remain close in the output space, even when subjected to the non-linear transformations of the model

  • •

    Early during training most networks are initialized such that w⋅x⋅𝑤𝑥w\cdot x is in a the linear region of the activation function which is where updates occur (He et al., 2015; Heaton, 2018). While this may breakdown over training, the direction of early training has consequences for the final model.

Lemma 4: The total change in w𝑤w is proportional to the summed parallel component of all vectors in dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}

Let’s consider data vectors x∈𝒟𝑥𝒟x\in\mathcal{D}. The total loss for these data points is L=∑x∈𝒟L​(x)𝐿subscript𝑥𝒟𝐿𝑥L=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}}L(x). Using the fact that the derivative of a sum is the sum of the derivatives, we get ∇wL=∑x∈𝒟∇wL​(x)subscript∇𝑤𝐿subscript𝑥𝒟subscript∇𝑤𝐿𝑥\nabla_{w}L=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}}\nabla_{w}L(x). From our previous analysis we get that

Δ​w∝∑x∈𝒟∇ϕL​(x)⋅x∥.proportional-toΔ𝑤subscript𝑥𝒟⋅subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿𝑥subscript𝑥parallel-to\Delta w\propto\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x)\cdot x_{\parallel}. (C.1)

Note, we assume that the constant of proportionality is the same for all vectors. This constant is impacted by η𝜂\eta and ϕ′(.)\phi^{\prime}(.). For a given training round, η𝜂\eta remains the same for all vectors. Further, with random or He initialization of weights, the expected value of ϕ′(.)\phi^{\prime}(.) should be similar for all vectors.

Proposition 2: For normalized datasets, weight divergence in FL is bounded by the orientation of feature vectors across clients c∈C𝑐𝐶c\in C

We use the previous result (Equation C.1) but replace x∥subscript𝑥parallel-tox_{\parallel} with ‖x‖​cos⁡(θx​w)norm𝑥subscript𝜃𝑥𝑤||x||\cos(\theta_{xw}) where θx​wsubscript𝜃𝑥𝑤\theta_{xw} is the angle between the weight and feature vector. As ‖x‖=1norm𝑥1||x||=1 this simplifies to cos⁡(θx​w)subscript𝜃𝑥𝑤\cos(\theta_{xw}). Then

Δ​w∝∑x∈𝒟∇ϕL​(x)​cos⁡(θx​w).proportional-toΔ𝑤subscript𝑥𝒟subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿𝑥subscript𝜃𝑥𝑤\Delta w\propto\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x)\cos(\theta_{xw}).

The global weight update across all clients c∈C𝑐𝐶c\in C is

Δ​wG=∑c=1Cαc​Δ​wc∝∑c=1Cαc​∑x∈𝒟c∇ϕL​(xc)​cos⁡(θxc​w).Δsuperscript𝑤𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑐1superscript𝛼𝑐Δsuperscript𝑤𝑐proportional-tosubscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑐1superscript𝛼𝑐subscript𝑥superscript𝒟𝑐subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐𝑤\Delta w^{G}=\sum^{C}_{c=1}\alpha^{c}\Delta w^{c}\propto\sum^{C}_{c=1}\alpha^{c}\sum_{x\in\mathcal{D}^{c}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{c})\cos(\theta_{x^{c}w}).

where αcsuperscript𝛼𝑐\alpha^{c} is the contribution of client c𝑐c to the global model and ∑c=1Cαc=1superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscript𝛼𝑐1\sum_{c=1}^{C}\alpha^{c}=1. Now we quantify the weight divergence between client k𝑘k and global model G𝐺G

|Δ​wG−Δ​wk|∝|∑c=1Cαc​∑xc∈𝒟c∇ϕL​(xc)​cos⁡(θxc​w)−∑xk∈𝒟k∇ϕL​(xk)​cos⁡(θxk​w)|.proportional-toΔsuperscript𝑤𝐺Δsuperscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscript𝛼𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝒟𝑐subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑘𝑤|\Delta w^{G}-\Delta w^{k}|\propto|\sum_{c=1}^{C}\alpha^{c}\sum_{x^{c}\in\mathcal{D}^{c}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{c})\cos(\theta_{x^{c}w})-\sum_{x^{k}\in\mathcal{D}^{k}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{k})\cos(\theta_{x^{k}w})|.

We now wish to create a direct comparison between data vectors from all clients but this is not directly possible. However, we can approximate the equation using a pairwise comparison across all data vectors in the datasets and then pair vectors based on high similarity. The full pairwise comparison then acts as an upper bound

|Δ​wG−Δ​wk|≤|∑c=1Cαc​∑xc∈𝒟c∑xk∈𝒟k∇ϕL​(xc)​cos⁡(θxc​w)−∇ϕL​(xk)​cos⁡(θxk​w)|.Δsuperscript𝑤𝐺Δsuperscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscript𝛼𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝒟𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐𝑤subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑘𝑤|\Delta w^{G}-\Delta w^{k}|\leq|\sum_{c=1}^{C}\alpha^{c}\sum_{x^{c}\in\mathcal{D}^{c}}\sum_{x^{k}\in\mathcal{D}^{k}}\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{c})\cos(\theta_{x^{c}w})-\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{k})\cos(\theta_{x^{k}w})|.

Utilizing the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction we get

|Δ​wG−Δ​wk|≤|∑c=1Cαc​∑xc∈𝒟c∑xk∈𝒟k(∇ϕL​(xc)−∇ϕL​(xk))​(cos⁡(θxc​w)−cos⁡(θxk​w))|.Δsuperscript𝑤𝐺Δsuperscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscript𝛼𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝒟𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐𝑤subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑘𝑤|\Delta w^{G}-\Delta w^{k}|\leq|\sum_{c=1}^{C}\alpha^{c}\sum_{x^{c}\in\mathcal{D}^{c}}\sum_{x^{k}\in\mathcal{D}^{k}}(\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{c})-\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{k}))(\cos(\theta_{x^{c}w})-\cos(\theta_{x^{k}w}))|.

Note, this step assumes that the gradients are Lipschitz continuous and that differences in gradients and cosine similarity of feature vectors to the weights interact linearly. This is an acceptable assumption as all clients share the same weights and loss function. Then using the inequality in preliminary 6

|Δ​wG−Δ​wk|≤|∑c=1Cαc​∑xc∈𝒟c∑xk∈𝒟k(∇ϕL​(xc)−∇ϕL​(xk))​(2​(1−cos⁡(θxc​xk)))|.Δsuperscript𝑤𝐺Δsuperscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscript𝛼𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝒟𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝒟𝑘subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑘21subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝑥𝑘|\Delta w^{G}-\Delta w^{k}|\leq|\sum_{c=1}^{C}\alpha^{c}\sum_{x^{c}\in\mathcal{D}^{c}}\sum_{x^{k}\in\mathcal{D}^{k}}(\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{c})-\nabla_{\phi}L(x^{k}))(\sqrt{2\left(1-\cos(\theta_{x^{c}x^{k}})\right)})|.

We now have a bound that’s based on the relative orientation of feature vectors to weight divergence. It can be seen that weight divergence is minimized when the feature vectors are perfectly oriented together between datasets.

Corollary 2: This pairwise comparison is equivalent to constructing a pairwise matrix, M𝑀M, across all data points in client k𝑘k with all other clients ∈Cabsent𝐶\in C such that each entry of M𝑀M is

Mi​j=|∇ϕL​(x)c−∇ϕL​(x)k⋅2​(1−cos⁡(θxc​xk))|.subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑐⋅subscript∇italic-ϕ𝐿superscript𝑥𝑘21subscript𝜃superscript𝑥𝑐superscript𝑥𝑘M_{ij}=|\nabla_{\phi}L(x)^{c}-\nabla_{\phi}L(x)^{k}\cdot\sqrt{2\left(1-\cos(\theta_{x^{c}x^{k}})\right)}|.

M𝑀M is an upper bound that is pairwise across all costs. However, it is more appropriate to have a sample-to-sample mapping between the datasets. This is because data vectors appear once in a training update. To achieve this mapping we can take the minimum coupling, π𝜋\pi.

arg ​minπ∈Π​∑i,jπi,j​Mi,jarg 𝜋Πminsubscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑀𝑖𝑗\text{arg }\underset{\pi\in\Pi}{\text{min}}\sum_{i,j}\pi_{i,j}M_{i,j}

where π𝜋\pi satisfies the constraints of mass conservation between datasets 𝒟csuperscript𝒟𝑐\mathcal{D}^{c} and 𝒟ksuperscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{k}.

Limitations: The proofs rely on simplifying assumptions that do not capture the complexities of deeper networks which are impacted by other factors. Rather, our goal is to show that relative feature orientation plays an important role in weight divergence.

Appendix D. Experiments

In this section we describe in more detail the experimental setup and present additional results referenced in the main manuscript. All dataset processing, models and hyperparameters are available at github.com/annoymous-submissions/ot_cost.

D.1 Setup: Datasets, Training, and models

Table D.1 describes how we partitioned datasets to produce datasets with specific dataset dissimilarity scores. We employ a mixture of feature and label skew Hsieh et al. (2020); Zhao et al. (2018).

  • •

    Synthetic: We draw samples from 2 distinct distributions, 𝒟asubscript𝒟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a} and 𝒟bsubscript𝒟𝑏\mathcal{D}_{b}. For partition 1 we always draw samples from 𝒟asubscript𝒟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a} and for partition 2 we vary the proportion of samples drawn from 𝒟asubscript𝒟𝑎\mathcal{D}_{a} and 𝒟bsubscript𝒟𝑏\mathcal{D}_{b}.

  • •

    Credit: We introduce increasing amounts of label skew and feature noise to the datasets. Label skew is achieved by introducing label distribution bias. For example, a 10% bias means 10% more positive labels and negative labels in partition 1 and 2, respectively. Feature noise is achieved by adding Gaussian noise.

  • •

    Weather: We partition datasets based on climate as described by Malinin et al. (2022). This introduces real-world feature and label skew.

  • •

    EMNIST: We partition datasets based on labels.

  • •

    CIFAR: We partition the dataset based on labels.

  • •

    IXITiny: We partition based on site. This is a natural partition. Sites Guys and Hammersmith use a Philips system with similar settings. Site IOP uses a GE system with unknown settings (see Brain-development.org, ; Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022).

  • •

    ISIC2019: We partition based on site. This is a natural paritition.

D.1.1 Setup: Training and Models

For each combination of dataset, cost, and training, we performed learning rate and optimizer tuning via grid search. We evaluate five learning rates (5​e−1,1​e−1,5​e−2,1​e−2,5​e−3,5​e−45superscript𝑒11superscript𝑒15superscript𝑒21superscript𝑒25superscript𝑒35superscript𝑒45e^{-1},1e^{-1},5e^{-2},1e^{-2},5e^{-3},5e^{-4}) and two optimizers (ADAM and SGD). The SGD optimizer is exclusively used for federated algorithms. For pFedME we use the pFedME optimizer released by the authors. For CIFAR, IXITiny and ISIC2019 we utilize pre-trained models that we fine-tune. Below we describe the model, learning rates, optimizers, and regularization parameters (for pFedME and Ditto only) for each dataset.

Synthetic

We use a MLP with 2 hidden layers of size 18 and 6.

Credit

We use a MLP with 3 hidden layers of size 56, 56 and 28.

Weather

We use a MLP with 3 hidden layers of size 123, 123 and 50.

EMNIST

We use a LeNet-5 CNN.

CIFAR

We use a pre-trained ResNet-18, freezing layers 1-3.

IXITiny

We use a pre-trained 3D Unet and allow training of all layers.

ISIC2019

We use a pre-trained efficientNet and allow training of all layers.

D.2 Results: Estimates Using Privacy-preserving Calculations

Figure D.1 compares the calculated score from the plain-text algorithms and the privacy-preserving algorithms. We show that the MPC protocol introduces no error (≤1​e−6absent1superscript𝑒6\leq 1e^{-6}) when calculating featuere costs and the z-CDP protocol introduces minimal error across most label comparisons.

D.3 Results: Synthetic Results for Costs >0.5absent0.5>0.5

Figure D.2 presents the results obtained from synthetic datasets with scores of 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0. To generate these datasets, we employed a combination of label switching and feature distributions that are deliberately contrasting. While such a scenario may not directly mirror real-world conditions, it helps with intuition of our score.

D.4 Results: Weight Divergence Correlation

We assess the relationship between weight divergence and two metrics: our proposed metric and the original Wasserstein distance using Pearson correlation tests (Table D.9). Our findings indicate that our metric consistently exhibits a higher correlation across all datasets when compared to the original Wasserstein distance (p=0.012absent0.012=0.012).

D.5 Results: MPC Runtime Complexity

Dot product

Using the protocol outline by Du et al. (2004), the runtime complexity of the dot product protocol is O​(n2​d+d2)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑑superscript𝑑2O(n^{2}d+d^{2}). Here, n𝑛n is the number of samples and d𝑑d is the vector dimension. The O​(d2)𝑂superscript𝑑2O(d^{2}) term arises from inversion of an MDS code matrix Jog (2004). The dominating term in the complexity depends on the relative size of sample count, n𝑛n, to the dataset dimension, d𝑑d.

Euclidean distance

We also analyzed a protocol by Ravikumar et al. (2004) to calculate euclidean distance in MPC. We chose this protocol as it also does not require encryption making it computationally efficient. The protocol provides a probabilistic estimate of the euclidean distance based on the number of indices from each vector that is used in the secure intersection step of the protocol. If one desires an exact euclidean distance estimate, then all indices must be sampled and the complexity is O(n2(d+dlog(d))O(n^{2}(d+dlog(d)) where n𝑛n is the number of samples and d𝑑d is the vector dimension.

D.6 Results: Hyperparameters

In this section we present sensitivity analysis for hyperparameters.

D.6.1 Regularization Parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon

We conducted sensitivity analysis on the regularization parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon evaluating results obtained from 5​e−35superscript𝑒35e^{-3}, 1​e−21superscript𝑒21e^{-2}, 5​e−25superscript𝑒25e^{-2}, 1​e−11superscript𝑒11e^{-1}, 5​e−15superscript𝑒15e^{-1} 1, 10, 100, 1000, 10000, compared to the baseline ϵ=1​e−3italic-ϵ1superscript𝑒3\epsilon=1e^{-3}. Our findings indicate that at values below 5e−2superscript5𝑒25^{e}{-2} the results are largely consistent (Figure D.3).

D.6.2 Feature-to-label Ratio (λ𝜆\lambda)

We conduct a sensitivity analysis on the feature-to-cost label ratio. Our baseline, 2:1, arises from the fact that cosine similarity and Hellinger distance range from 0-2 and 0-1, respectively. We compare ratios: 1:1, 1:2, 1:3, 1:4, 1:5, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1. Our results show that the score is robust to a range of ratios within the 1:4-4:1 (Figure D.4).

Appendix E. Privacy Guarantees

This section covers the analysis for the combined application of MPC and z-CDP to calculate feature and label costs, respectively.

Setup

Let sites 1 and 2 hold datasets X∈ℝn×d𝑋superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} and Y∈ℝn×d𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} where n𝑛n is the number of samples and d𝑑d is the dataset dimension, respectively. All samples in X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y belong to a specific label class c∈C𝑐𝐶c\in C where C={c1,..,cl}C=\{c_{1},..,c_{l}\}. We use Xcsubscript𝑋𝑐X_{c} and Ycsubscript𝑌𝑐Y_{c} to denote the samples in X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y that belong to label class c𝑐c. Algorithm 1 releases the following information to the server:

  1. 1.

    X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}, the cosine similarity matrix calculated using MPC (Section B.2)

  2. 2.

    μXc′subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′\mu_{X_{c}^{\prime}} and μYc′,∀c∈Csubscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′for-all𝑐𝐶\mu_{Y_{c}^{\prime}},\forall c\in C, the noised column means of Xcsubscript𝑋𝑐X_{c} and Ycsubscript𝑌𝑐Y_{c} such that μXc′=μXc+e1subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′subscript𝜇subscript𝑋𝑐subscript𝑒1\mu_{X_{c}^{\prime}}=\mu_{X_{c}}+e_{1} and μYc′=μYc+e2subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′subscript𝜇subscript𝑌𝑐subscript𝑒2\mu_{Y_{c}^{\prime}}=\mu_{Y_{c}}+e_{2} where e1,e2subscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2e_{1},e_{2} are noise vectors generated using a ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP mechanism.

  3. 3.

    Xc′⁣T​Xc′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′X_{c}^{\prime T}X_{c}^{\prime} and Yc′⁣T​Yc′,∀c∈Csuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′for-all𝑐𝐶Y_{c}^{\prime T}Y_{c}^{\prime},\forall c\in C, the noised covariance matrices of Xcsubscript𝑋𝑐X_{c} and Ycsubscript𝑌𝑐Y_{c} such that Xc′⁣T​Xc′=XcT​XC+E1superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑇subscript𝑋𝐶subscript𝐸1X_{c}^{\prime T}X_{c}^{\prime}=X_{c}^{T}X_{C}+E_{1} and Yc′⁣T​Yc′=YcT​Yc+E2superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐𝑇subscript𝑌𝑐subscript𝐸2Y_{c}^{\prime T}Y_{c}^{\prime}=Y_{c}^{T}Y_{c}+E_{2} where E1,E2subscript𝐸1subscript𝐸2E_{1},E_{2} are symmetric noise matrices generated using a ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP mechanism.

Threat Model

In our threat model we assume the adversary has access to all released information (X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}, μXc′subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′\mu_{X_{c}^{\prime}}, μYc′subscript𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′\mu_{Y_{c}^{\prime}}, Xc′⁣T​Xc′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑐′X_{c}^{\prime T}X_{c}^{\prime}, Yc′⁣T​Yc′superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑐′Y_{c}^{\prime T}Y_{c}^{\prime}) and aims to reconstruct X𝑋X or Y𝑌Y.

Assumptions

We make the following assumptions on X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y:

  • •

    All samples in X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y are independent.

  • •

    All samples in X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y belong to one class such that Xc=Xsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑋X_{c}=X and Yc=Ysubscript𝑌𝑐𝑌Y_{c}=Y. Consequently, the summary statistics of the full datasets are released. This represents a worst-case scenario.

  • •

    X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y are column-centered and row-normalized independently. This pre-processing is a requirement of Algorithm 1. This has the following implications:

    1. 1.

      Row-normalization ensures that each entry xi​jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{ij} of X𝑋X satisfies |xi​j|≤1subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗1|x_{ij}|\leq 1.

    2. 2.

      As a consequence of 1, the entries of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} are bounded by -1 and 1, with the diagonal entries being 1.

    3. 3.

      As a consequence of 1, the diagonal entries of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X, which represent the variance of the features, is at most 1313\frac{1}{3}. This arises under a uniform distribution with values xi​jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗x_{ij} between -1 and 1.

    4. 4.

      Column centering prior to calculating μX′subscript𝜇superscript𝑋′\mu_{X^{\prime}} and μY′subscript𝜇superscript𝑌′\mu_{Y^{\prime}} ensures that μX′subscript𝜇superscript𝑋′\mu_{X^{\prime}} and μY′subscript𝜇superscript𝑌′\mu_{Y^{\prime}} do not release information.

E.0.3 Proof Outline

Assuming that an adversary has access to X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime}, Y′⁣T​Y′superscript𝑌′𝑇superscript𝑌′Y^{\prime T}Y^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}, our goal is to determine what information regarding datasets X𝑋X or Y𝑌Y can be leaked. Without loss of generality, we focus on X𝑋X. To quantify the leakage, we bound the ability of an adversary to reconstruct X𝑋X using X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}. In summary, an adversary can reconstruct X𝑋X up to an orthonormal basis if the singular vectors of X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} are sufficiently close to XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T}, respectively. In the proof, we bound how closely the singular vectors of X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} can approximate the singular vectors of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T}.

The proof relies on matrix perturbation theory framing X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} as perturbed versions of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T}. Under this framework, the singular vectors of X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} matrix can only approximate XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} when the spectral gap of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} , δ:=σ1−σ2assign𝛿subscript𝜎1subscript𝜎2\delta:=\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2} is larger than the spectral norm of the perturbation (Vu, 2011). We show that, under some assumptions and constraints on the data, the perturbation is larger than the upper bound of the spectral gaps in both X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}.

Preliminaries

We use the following preliminaries:

  1. 1.

    Singular value decomposition (SVD):

    • •

      The SVD of X𝑋X is expressed as X=UX​ΣX​VX𝑋subscript𝑈𝑋subscriptΣ𝑋subscript𝑉𝑋X=U_{X}\Sigma_{X}V_{X} which are the left singular vectors, singular values, and right singular vectors, respectively.

    • •

      The SVD decomposition of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} yields UXsubscript𝑈𝑋U_{X} and ΣXsubscriptΣ𝑋\Sigma_{X} and the SVD decomposition of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X yields VXsubscript𝑉𝑋V_{X} and ΣXsubscriptΣ𝑋\Sigma_{X}.

    • •

      With UXsubscript𝑈𝑋U_{X}, ΣXsubscriptΣ𝑋\Sigma_{X}, and VXsubscript𝑉𝑋V_{X} it is possible to reconstruct X𝑋X up to an orthonormal basis.

  2. 2.

    Matrix trace: The trace of a matrix A𝐴A is the sum of the diagonal elements, t​r​(A)=Σi=1n​ai,i𝑡𝑟𝐴subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑖tr(A)=\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}a_{i,i}. The trace is also sum of the eigenvalues, σ𝜎\sigma, of A𝐴A, t​r​(A)=∑i=1nσi𝑡𝑟𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝜎𝑖tr(A)=\sum^{n}_{i=1}\sigma_{i}.

  3. 3.

    Norms:

    • •

      The Frobenius norm of matrix A is ‖A‖F=Σi=1​Σj=1​ai​j2subscriptnorm𝐴𝐹subscriptΣ𝑖1subscriptΣ𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗2||A||_{F}=\sqrt{\Sigma_{i=1}\Sigma_{j=1}a_{ij}^{2}}

    • •

      The spectral norm of a matrix, ||.||||.||, is the maximum singular value of the matrix, max{σi}i=1n\max\{\sigma_{i}\}^{n}_{i=1} for a matrix with singular values σ1,…,σnsubscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑛\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{n}

    • •

      The spectral norm is upper bounded by the Frobenius norm, ||.||≤||.||F||.||\leq||.||_{F}

  4. 4.

    Spectral norm of random matrix: Let E𝐸E be a random symmetric matrix in ℝd×dsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} where each entry ei∼N​(0,σ)similar-tosubscript𝑒𝑖𝑁0𝜎e_{i}\sim N(0,\sigma) then:

    2​σ​d−c​ln​d≥‖E‖≤2​σ​d+c​d14​ln​d2𝜎𝑑𝑐ln𝑑norm𝐸2𝜎𝑑𝑐superscript𝑑14ln𝑑\displaystyle 2\sigma\sqrt{d}-c\text{ln}d\geq||E||\leq 2\sigma\sqrt{d}+cd^{\frac{1}{4}}\text{ln}d

    for some constant c𝑐c. As n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty then ‖E‖norm𝐸||E|| is expected to be at least 2​σ​n2𝜎𝑛2\sigma\sqrt{n} Vu (2005).

  5. 5.

    Spectral gap: The spectral gap of a matrix, δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}, is defined as δi:=σi−σi+1assignsubscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖1\delta_{i}:=\sigma_{i}-\sigma_{i+1} where σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} is the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} singular value.

  6. 6.

    Wedin Sin theorem: This theorem provides a bound on how closely the singular vectors of a perturbed matrix, A′superscript𝐴′A^{\prime} approximates the singular vectors of the original matrix, A𝐴A

    s​i​n​Θ​(VA,VA′)≤C​‖E‖δ𝑠𝑖𝑛Θsubscript𝑉𝐴subscript𝑉superscript𝐴′𝐶norm𝐸𝛿\displaystyle sin\Theta(V_{A},V_{A^{\prime}})\leq C\frac{||E||}{\delta}

    where δ𝛿\delta is the first spectral gap, VA,VA′subscript𝑉𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑉𝐴′V_{A},V_{A}^{\prime} are the singular vectors, ‖E‖norm𝐸||E|| is the spectral norm of the perturbation matrix E𝐸E and C𝐶C is a constant >0absent0>0. If δ≥C​‖E‖𝛿𝐶norm𝐸\delta\geq C||E|| then:

    s​i​n​Θ​(VA,VA′)≤ϵ.𝑠𝑖𝑛Θsubscript𝑉𝐴subscript𝑉superscript𝐴′italic-ϵ\displaystyle sin\Theta(V_{A},V_{A^{\prime}})\leq\epsilon.

    However, if δ<C​‖E‖𝛿𝐶norm𝐸\delta<C||E|| then it no longer holds that VA′subscript𝑉superscript𝐴′V_{A^{\prime}} closely approximates VAsubscript𝑉𝐴V_{A} (Vu, 2011).

  7. 7.

    Jensen’s inequality: Jensen’s inequality for a convex function f(.)f(.) states

    f​(1n​Σi=1n​xi)≤1n​Σi=1n​f​(xi).𝑓1𝑛subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑥𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle f\left(\frac{1}{n}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}x_{i}\right)\leq\frac{1}{n}\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}f(x_{i}).

Lemma 1: The spectral gaps of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X are n𝑛n and d3𝑑3\frac{d}{3}, respectively

Let X​XT∈ℝn×n𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛XX^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} and XT​X∈ℝd×dsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑X^{T}X\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} where n𝑛n and d𝑑d are the number of samples and features, respectively. This proof relies on showing that the spectral gaps of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X, δX​XTsubscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇\delta_{XX^{T}} and δXT​Xsubscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋\delta_{X^{T}X} are less than the spectral norms of the perturbations. To do this, we first establish upper bounds on δX​XTsubscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇\delta_{XX^{T}} and δXT​Xsubscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋\delta_{X^{T}X}, leveraging the fact that both X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X are symmetric matrices and X𝑋X is row-normalized. In the case of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T}, the bound is

δX​XT<n.subscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇𝑛\delta_{XX^{T}}<n.

The upper bound arises as Σi=1n​σi=t​r​(X​XT)subscriptsuperscriptΣ𝑛𝑖1subscript𝜎𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}\sigma_{i}=tr(XX^{T}), and under the assumption that all of this is concentrated on σ1subscript𝜎1\sigma_{1} with σ2→0→subscript𝜎20\sigma_{2}\rightarrow 0. Since the diagonal entries of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} are all one (due to row-normalization), t​r​(X​XT)=n𝑡𝑟𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇𝑛tr(XX^{T})=n.
For XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X, δXT​Xsubscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋\delta_{X^{T}X} is bounded as

δXT​X<d3.subscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋𝑑3\delta_{X^{T}X}<\frac{d}{3}.

This upper bound is derived from the fact that the diagonal entries of XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X, which represent the variance of the features, are ≤13absent13\leq\frac{1}{3} (see Section Assumptions) and all of this concentrated in σ1subscript𝜎1\sigma_{1}. Consequently, t​r​(XT​X)=d3𝑡𝑟superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋𝑑3tr(X^{T}X)=\frac{d}{3}. Note, these are upper bounds the gap is likely lower in real-world datasets with low intrinsic rank Vu (2011).

Proof 1: Bounding the Information from Releasing X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime}

Next, we bound how closely the VX′⁣T​X′subscript𝑉superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′V_{X^{\prime T}X^{\prime}} approximates VXT​Xsubscript𝑉superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋V_{X^{T}X}. Let E𝐸E be the perturbation matrix where each entry ei∼N​(0,Δ22​ρ2)similar-tosubscript𝑒𝑖𝑁0superscriptΔ22superscript𝜌2e_{i}\sim N(0,\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2\rho^{2}}) and Δ=2n​(d+2​d​l​o​g​(n/βs)+2​l​o​g​(n/βs))Δ2𝑛𝑑2𝑑𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑛subscript𝛽𝑠2𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑛subscript𝛽𝑠\Delta=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{n}\left(d+2\sqrt{dlog(n/\beta_{s})}+2log(n/\beta_{s})\right) where ρ𝜌\rho and βssubscript𝛽𝑠\beta_{s} are user defined parameters based on the privacy-budget (we set β=0.01,ρ=0.1formulae-sequence𝛽0.01𝜌0.1\beta=0.01,\rho=0.1). We can set a lower bound for ΔΔ\Delta and σ𝜎\sigma as Δ≥2​dnΔ2𝑑𝑛\Delta\geq\frac{\sqrt{2}d}{n} and σ≥dρ​n𝜎𝑑𝜌𝑛\sigma\geq\frac{d}{\rho n}. Using the result for a spectral norm of a random matrix, E𝐸E, we get

‖E‖≥2​d32ρ​n.norm𝐸2superscript𝑑32𝜌𝑛||E||\geq\frac{2d^{\frac{3}{2}}}{\rho n}.

Thus, as long as the privacy parameters are appropriately set, then ‖E‖>δXT​X=d3norm𝐸subscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋𝑑3||E||>\delta_{X^{T}X}=\frac{d}{3}. Specifically, the bound on the privacy parameters is

6​d12n>ρ,6superscript𝑑12𝑛𝜌\frac{6d^{\frac{1}{2}}}{n}>\rho,

then ‖E‖>δXT​Xnorm𝐸subscript𝛿superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋||E||>\delta_{X^{T}X}. Appropriately setting ρ𝜌\rho should ensure sufficient protection. Across all our datasets, ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1 met this criterion but this will vary depending on the specific datasets.

Proof 2: Bounding the Information from Releasing X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T}

Next, we bound how closely the VX​YTsubscript𝑉𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇V_{XY^{T}} approximates VX​XTsubscript𝑉𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇V_{XX^{T}}. To do this, we quantify how much X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y must differ such that X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} does not reveal UX​XTsubscript𝑈𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇U_{XX^{T}}. This is an argument on the overlap in samples of X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y. For example, in an extreme case, if all samples overlap then X​XT=X​YT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XX^{T}=XY^{T} and UX​XTsubscript𝑈𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇U_{XX^{T}} is perfectly approximated by UX​YTsubscript𝑈𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇U_{XY^{T}}. To estimate the minimum difference, we leverage the fact that X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} are bounded -1,1. We define the perturbation matrix P=X​YT−X​XT𝑃𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇P=XY^{T}-XX^{T}. When samples in X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y overlap, entries in P𝑃P will be 00, otherwise entries will be non-zero. We can bound spectral norm of P𝑃P using the Frobenius norm of P𝑃P by using the fact that ‖P‖≤‖P‖Fnorm𝑃subscriptnorm𝑃𝐹||P||\leq||P||_{F} and ‖P‖Fsubscriptnorm𝑃𝐹||P||_{F} is itself bounded as all entries in X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} are between -1,1

0≤‖P‖≤‖P‖F≤2​n.0norm𝑃subscriptnorm𝑃𝐹2𝑛0\leq||P||\leq||P||_{F}\leq 2n.

The lower bound arises when X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} are identical and the upper bound occurs when every X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} maximally differ and entries pi​j=−2​or​2subscript𝑝𝑖𝑗2or2p_{ij}=-2\text{or}2. To obtain how much X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y can differ for ‖P‖>δX​XT=nnorm𝑃subscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇𝑛||P||>\delta_{XX^{T}}=n, we derive a bound on ‖P‖Fsubscriptnorm𝑃𝐹||P||_{F}. Let αF=1n​(n−1)​Σ​pi​j2subscript𝛼𝐹1𝑛𝑛1Σsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗2\alpha_{F}=\frac{1}{n(n-1)}\Sigma p_{ij}^{2} such that αFsubscript𝛼𝐹\alpha_{F} represents the average squared contribution of pi​jsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗p_{ij} to ‖P‖Fsubscriptnorm𝑃𝐹||P||_{F}. Let α=(1n​(n−1)​Σ​pi​j)2𝛼superscript1𝑛𝑛1Σsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑗2\alpha=\left(\frac{1}{n(n-1)}\Sigma p_{ij}\right)^{2} such that α𝛼\alpha represents the mean entry of P𝑃P squared. As entries in P𝑃P are between -2,2, α𝛼\alpha ranges from 0,4. We are actually interested in αFsubscript𝛼𝐹\alpha_{F} but invoke Jensen’s inequality to lower bound αFsubscript𝛼𝐹\alpha_{F} by α𝛼\alpha. In this case, a threshold is needed such that X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} does not reveal UX​XTsubscript𝑈𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇U_{XX^{T}}. This threshold is

αF​n≥α​n>n.subscript𝛼𝐹𝑛𝛼𝑛𝑛\sqrt{\alpha_{F}}n\geq\sqrt{\alpha}n>n.

It is clear that α𝛼\alpha must be ≥1absent1\geq 1 for ‖P‖>δX​XTnorm𝑃subscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇||P||>\delta_{XX^{T}}. As α𝛼\alpha ranges from 0,4 (as entries in P𝑃P, or α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}, range from -2,2), a requirement of α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1 suggests Y𝑌Y must differ by at least a 25% difference in entries between X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} and X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T}. Note, this bound assumes δX​YT=nsubscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇𝑛\delta_{XY^{T}}=n which is conservative. In reality, δX​YTsubscript𝛿𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇\delta_{XY^{T}} is smaller and α𝛼\alpha can be less than 1.

Limitations

We assume worse-case spectral gaps of X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and XT​Xsuperscript𝑋𝑇𝑋X^{T}X. A tighter bound on the spectral gaps would reduce the level noise added to X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and the necessary deviation between X​XT𝑋superscript𝑋𝑇XX^{T} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} to prevent reconstruction. We have not pursued these tighter bounds as they are dataset specific. Further, we do not consider repeated release of different matrices (e.g., repeated release with different differential privacy noise) as our setting differs from querying databases. X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} and X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} are released only once in our scenario.

Conclusion

We have demonstrated that the release of X′⁣T​X′superscript𝑋′𝑇superscript𝑋′X^{\prime T}X^{\prime} and X​YT𝑋superscript𝑌𝑇XY^{T} will not allow for the reconstruction of X𝑋X.
